Comment: You missed my point-- the point is the SCOTUS is looking at protecting the rights of US citizens under their decision to allow Trump's ban with limits. That means protecting the rights of US Citizens or legal residents under the US constitution. Non citizens and non legal residents do not have constitutional rights (except possibly under very rare circumstances). The constitutional rights of a citizen or legal resident could include hiring immigrants without unconstitutional bars such as religion (a US Citizen could have a constitutional right to hire a Muslim), or for a US Citizen to have their spouse immigrate to the US even if they are Muslims, or to have your child immigrate free of discrimination (assuming they are not in violation of other laws or rules-- immigration fraud, criminal violations, being a terrorist, etc.). Therefore, the SCOTUS order striking down Trump's ban had this "connection" provision to protect US Citizens and legal residents.

Comment: According to the World Bank, there are 3 billion people on this planet living on $2/day or less.  Another 2.6 billion live in countries with lower incomes than Mexico's.  A third of the world's people don't have access to clean water or electricity, both of which require access to cheap energy ... the most practical and accessible being coal-fired power plants that don't require as much capital investment as nuclear, wind, and solar; nor the network of natural gas pipelines that this country has. And coal-fired plants work when the wind isn't blowing and the sun isn't shining.  

I think 5.6 billion people would consider having clean water and electricity a higher priority than lowering the average temperature half a degree over the next 50 years.  This is why India and China (where many of the poor live) are exempt from the emissions standards of the Paris Accords.  Their emissions increases offset our reductions.  Nothing is being accomplished.

Get your priorities straight.

Comment: LOTL, that petition you mention in your last sentence can be read in John's Gospel  (17:21). Since you made the sentence an exclamation, I presume that you, like me, recognize just how pivotal is the petition to (and how definitional of) any genuine claim to be Jesus' disciple. What exactly was Jesus asking of his Father? If you read to the end of the chapter, the answer is clearly stated: "...that the love with which thou hast loved me may be in them, and I in them." (The New Oxford Annotated Bible, v 26)

The unity Jesus seeks of his followers is primarily a unity in love, not doctrine. I don't deny the importance of doctrine, but I do deny that it has supreme importance. Belief in (intellectual assent to) the dogma of the Eucharist cannot redeem a person: only Eucharistic love, manifested in and through word and deed, can do this. Note, however, that intellectual assent to Eucharistic dogma is not a condition for exercising the love referenced by the dogma.

Comment: PS—I hope I’m not breaking any rules by commenting further.  But your statement,  ‘We aren't talking about biologically determined roles but social constructed exclusion based solely on gender’ intrigued me.  I think you may draw too firm a line between biology and culture.  You see, culture is part of our biology, because we are quintessentially social animals.  As I said to Nora—politely, I hope—there’s not a vertebrate I can think of that doesn’t have a sexual division of labour.  Often the division is apparently arbitrary and not based on size or strength.  I don’t think humans are any different.  The cultural constructs that emerge are conditioned by and large by our biology.  That’s why I think the secular modernist concept of ‘gender equality’ is (a) absurd, (b) bound to fail, and (c) the root cause of much of modern neurosis (including gender confusion).

Comment: Dark Web . . . .  ooh that must mean it's bad.  Right?

Wrong!  Corporate media just can't seem to report alternative networks that are accessible via the internet accurately without participating in social engineering.

The most popular and ubiquitous alternate network is call the TOR Network.  It was developed in the 1990's by the US Navy for intelligence communications over the internet.  It provides anonymity using encryption and a routing technique called 'onion routing'.

TOR is used by all sort of people including Edward Snowden and Wikileaks, numerous law enforcement and intelligence agencies as well as many ordinary people throughout the world who value their privacy.  As these types of so-called journalistic reports inform, it is also used by some unsavory people as well.

So when one sees media use the disparaging term "Dark Web" this is what you are not being told.

Comment: The Church has already "confronted" the issue of women's ordination.  A final  decision on that issue has been reached.  The Church has no authority to ordain women.  I don't understand why this is not clear to dissidents.  What would the Church have to do before they finally realize this cannot change? Why do they act like this issue is open for discussion or that the Church can somehow "move forward" on this issue. 

The deaconate is, at this time, in theory open to women.  That question has not been answered definitively. However, research into this issue has already been done as to what the deaconate was in the early Church.  The conclusion has been that it was not what is understood today to be the Sacrament of Holy Orders deaconate.  

Whatever the case may be--what is known with certainty at this time is that women will never be ordained to the priesthood or episcopate.  There is no "moving forward" on this.  Rome has spoken, the case is closed.

Comment: Pardon me for my cynicism, but where do you think the electricity comes from that powers the lithium batteries? If you're thinking solar and wind, you're dreaming.  Though I acknowledge charging at night is good use of surplus electricity.

US$35K, for a car with a sketchy reliability track record (Tesla) is certainly a car for the brave.
350 km range will be significantly shorter in the winter; up to 40% less.  Battery life will also be significantly shorter. (see above disposal issue).

Comment: "...fear is a personal issue, and it's not up to Parliament to censure it or decide on means to "quell" it."

Ignorance is a personal issue too. People have the right to remain in fear and ignorance both. But as a society we constantly seek ways to lessen ignorance.We do it both for the individual's and society's benefit.

A phobia is an extreme and irrational fear. You could describe it as ignorance and fear combined. Society doesn't care if you're just afraid of spiders, that's your business. But if your phobia is of other people, you  are going to be inclined to act against them in anti-social ways. So yes, just as it's in society's interest to lessen ignorance, it's in society's interest to lessen irrational fears.

Comment: Newman supports me as I've shown above and that is good enough for me. 
If the Magisterium can err then the Church has no authority to teach. The Church, however, received the authority to teach from Christ, Himself: Christ cannot err, therefore His Church cannot err.
The old chestnut about slavery is easily disposed of. Did Christ tolerate slavery? No. It was part of the fabric of society in those days and there is no doubt that there were very many abuses of the system. 
Similarly the medieval Feudal System incorporated many abuses. Both systems probably allowed millions to survive and live relatively comfortable lives who would have otherwise died very early in life in abject poverty.
Our modus vivendi today is far from perfect so it is hypocritical for us to stand in judgement on our ancestors.

Comment: "A major reason for the strike is job security for union members."

in my eyes - THERE IS NO SUCH THING AS JOB SECURITY!   job security only comes from an individual's singular ability to provide the type of skills needed to accomplish the given task required by an employer at the rate being offered.  as long as that person has the ability to learn and master that particular skill, that person should be the one to get the job at that rate.  

that's where competition comes into play.  and that's what the market place is all about!  if a person can provide that needed skill at a MUTUALLY AGREEABLE RATE between the worker and management, which may or may not be at the going rate OR LESS, that is the point where there might be an employment relationship.  

NOTHING IS GUARANTEED, IN WRITING OR VERBALLY, CONTRACTUALLY OR OTHERWISE.  the person provides the skill needed at the rate being suggested by the employer - and it is not guaranteed!  NO MORE, NO LESS!

Comment: Galactic Hero: The issue is not aircraft design but air density -- which is, in part, determined by temperature. Higher temperature correlates with lower air density, which offers less lift. The problem is in the physics.

It will be almost impossible for Trudeau to achieve his vaunted new relationship with First Nations and keep the remaining 96% of Canadians mollified. And his broader predilection for identity pandering increasingly irritates many Canadians. The risks ahead are all Trudeau's to face.

Comment: This is not a fake, made-up situation.  As a retired therapist, I've seen this time and time again. Although I don't believe counselling or therapy is the answer for every human problem, in this instance some sessions with an experienced couples counsellor to clarify the issues, to translate each partner to the other, and to improve their communication would be the best preventive medicine.  Alternatively, it could reveal that they are fundamentally unsuited to each other and they might have to accept they made a mistake and move on. I've known couples who had a disastrous start to their marriage, followed by a rocky few years, but twenty years later are thriving, having learned to see things through their partner's eyes, to empathize, and to put coupledom ahead of short term individual interest (which can be maintained and even enhanced in a good relationship).

Comment: The interesting part of the Evergreen Line is that it came in under budget despite the problems encountered with soil condition that were unexpected. This is despite several delays contractor EGRT Construction ran into during tunnel boring, which added three months to the expected construction time.

Why?  Because the government had the foresight to sign a fixed cost contract with a well-experienced  contractor and it was the contractor that had to eat the extra costs for the tunneling and soil condition problems.  The BC government was adamant that the contractor fulfill its contractual obligations.  

Contrast that with the recent report on infrastructure construction mismanagement by the Ontario Liberal government by Ontario Auditor General Bonnie Lysyk.

Comment: Yeah, I know that many city dwellers read about this and say this is a good idea.  I can only suggest that some go out and look at the real terrain which is very hilly/mountainous with very steep slopes.  Also, invasive species, e.g. blackberries and scotch broom have decided they love the local climate and grow much faster than trees.  The invasive species kill little trees before they can grow high enough to dominate.  Aerial spraying is really the only way to reclaim steep terrain from invasive species.  A selective ban might be reasonable.  A total ban means that difficult terrain currently controlled by invasive species will remain so controlled in the many areas where machines cannot operate safely.  And every time, the blackberries or whatever gain the upper hand, they will keep it.  Eventually, much of the land on terrain where machinery cannot safely operate will be lost to invasive weeds.  So much for love of forests.

Comment: That's a good point. The push to CFLs may have actually delayed the adoption of much-better LEDs by a decade. 

The whole complaint about the market not accepting CFL's (and then LEDs) "fast enough" ignores what's likely the biggest reason it's such a slow transition... modern incandescents simply last a lot longer than they did decades ago and consumers typically only replace bulbs when they need replacing.  And they tend to have a supply in the closest to use up first before going out and buying new ones.  

Like CFLs. I probably have 30+ in a cupboard from when Costco was selling them for like $0.99 a 6-pack with automatic Xcel rebate.  So I'm kinda stuck using those for the next 20 years rather than buying LED replacements.

Now, in some high-usage cases I buy LEDs anyway (like the kitchen where the lights are on 6+ hours/day). But I've got so many damn CFLs now that I technically wouldn't have to buy another (regular size) bulb in my lifetime.

Comment: Ms Khalid defined Islamophobia in the Commons as "the irrational hatred of Muslims that leads to discrimination". Would it not have been good  if she or her party had expressed some recognition that a phobia is a fear, not a hatred, though fear can cause hatred?  Hence we have two words, "gynophobia"  for the fear of women  (from the Greek words for woman and  fear), and "misogyny" for the hatred or dislike or contempt for women (from the Greek words for woman and hate) .  Of course, a fear is an aversion and a hatred is an aversion , but that doesn't mean all aversions are hatreds.  And would it not  have been good, even in the 21st century,  not to define "Islamophobia" in a way that entailed that someone whose persistent and irrational fear of Muslims leads to flight behaviour, e.g. emigrating to Korea, rather than to discrimination was not an Islamophobe but had to be a phobe of some other unnamed sort? Let's hope the investigating committee has more linguistic sensitivity.

Comment: Many or most subcultures have practices considered repressive in the secular background culture.  If you're a Baptist you can't smoke or drink.  If you're Reformed you can smoke like a chimney and drink like a fish, but you can't dance or go to movies. If you're an Old Order Mennonite you can own a tractor, but your children are not allowed to attend a public school. If you're a David Martin Mennonite, you can't own a tractor, but your children may attend a public school.  And almost all these conservative cultures disallow premarital sex because it might lead to dancing. (Old joke, I know). The point is the people in these subcultures don't consider their life oppressive, and often there are compensations in their life style that you don't have.  There's a fine line between repression and growth through self-discipline, and you simply can't accuse someone else of repression for what they believe they are doing voluntarily.

Comment: Growth or no growth is not the question because growth can't be stopped.  Managed growth can ease the pain temporarily but it has not the answer either.  Our efforts to manage growth have resulted in more costly public services, more expensive housing, congested arterial roads, social problems related to concentration of the human population, and less accountability in public spending.  There is no element of the management scheme that deals with real costs and as a result managed growth has contributed to non-managed spending and a less desirable human living condition.  Throwing ever-growing amounts of money into the government coffers has not helped bring about more accountability or solutions to the problems created by population growth.  It is time to reconsider the basic equation of managed growth and its costs.  The Eyman propositions give us an opportunity to reconsider what is important in life and to rethink the myriad of harm that our efforts to manage growth have caused.

Comment: It is not hard for a scientist (i.e. not you) to figure out when orbital variations have affected our planet because they are periodic.  But because there are several layers to it the periodicity is not a simple recurrence of every X years.  In other words, some aspects have periods of, say, 75,000 years while others are longer.  When you layer them together it is complicated.  
The medieval warm period was not a global phenomenon, rather different portions of the planet warmed at different times, contrary to what you probably think.  In other words, there was no planet-wide forcing mechanism.  Same with the little ice age.  
I am not a hypocrite for pushing the idea that our actions our detrimental to our planet, as I take all kinds of efforts to reduce my impact which is probably a fraction of yours.

Comment: April 18, 1964.  The day the Vietnam War started for the US Air Force.  It was a Saturday.  Six of us recruits from the Bay Area arrived at Lackland Air Force Base for seven weeks of Basic Training.  We were immediately told that Training would last only five weeks and not seven weeks and that the last two weeks of training would be accomplished at out next training base. We got to Chanute AFB, IL, and found the training to be one week of "KP" and one week at the base swimming pool.  100 days after I started my honorable service, the "Gulf of Tonkin Incident" was claimed to have happened and the Resolution followed five days later.  The USAF was already "ready for war".  Do NOT thank me for my "service".  You may, however, thank me for being a victim of that fake war.

Comment: At the top of every cycle we get the same discussion. Retail investors start to think that they can save a few bucks by managing their on investments because the market only ever goes up and you can make money on every stock right?!  Now I will admit that if you devote your time to managing your own stock portfolio and you have access to the same research and tools and your broker then you can save money by not paying him/her to do the same job that you are anyways. The problem is that most people don't have the time to actively manage their own investments and when times are good they get complacent. Next things you know we have a correction and instead of rebalancing or rotating stocks out of their portfolio they wait and wind up getting crushed far more than they should have.

Not that it makes any difference to the author as it gets into the way of his story, but the TD was never accused of trying to sell investment services to unsuspecting clients.

Comment: Most of the comments here seem to be written by either supporters or haters of China. There seem to be two distinct opinions. 
PLease allow me to provide some perspective as somebody who has through his employment (recently retired) with one of Canada's largest retailers - three months each year travelling all over that country for more than 30 years. 
It is undeniable that China has improved - When I first went there the infrastructure was almost non existent, the poverty was heartbreaking, the pollution was simply incredible and there was virtually no social freedom. Over the 30 plus years there has been a giant improvement which is unequalled in any other country. However, there is still a great deal of work to be done. 
The haters still believe that it is still as it was 30 years ago and the supporters think that they have reached a pinnacle.
The truth is somewhere in between and I hope that Mr. Xi can continue to improve the lives of the Chinese people who deserve a better life.

Comment: Cathal Kelly has again written an elegant and insightful essay surveying our political landscape, reposted here: http://bit.ly/2i54pCU.  There is an antinomy in the essay. On the one hand, nostalgia is always surging upon us from whatever "non-special place" we happen to occupy in space and time. On the other hand, there are special moments and contexts that punctuate history and allow us to speak of "The Gilded Age:" or now the "Nostalgic Age". Nostalgia peaks most sharply in the face of trauma and dread. We prefer to look back from a precipice rather than forward beyond it. As we move over a precipice and survive, that experience can later be recovered nostalgically. Recall that Gott's somewhat reassuring calculations of human survival depend upon the assumption that there is no special circumstance associated with the moment of calculation. But we are now in a nuclear world and have entered the Anthropocene. The trauma and dread we face are neither mythic nor hypothetical.

Comment: What are company pension plans, RRSPs and TFSAs? Corporate passive savings accounts are referred to as "tax sheltered piggy banks" which is a completely insulting and untrue statement. Funds are taxed at a lower rate when they go in but all passive investments are subject to yearly taxation on investment income and capital gains disposition. Salaried employees have tax sheltered company pension plans and their RRSP contributions are completely tax deductible and tax sheltered. Anyone using a TFSA may pay more initial tax on funds going in but they are completely tax sheltered once in the account. Corporate passive investment is taxed at every stage going in, while in the plan and when finally going out at retirement.  To subject them to increased tax is an attack on the families of all small business owners.

Comment: What exactly would have happened and why when he went to hook up the positive cable?  Generally as long as the polarities are correct - Red (+) to Red (+) and Black (-) to Black (-) - the worst that might happen is a small spark.  The spark will only cause a problem if battery gases are present in enough concentration to explode and this is incredibly rare with modern batteries.  The advice is to hook up the dead battery negative last and to hook it to a solid ground in the car.  Unfortunately there is so much plastic and shrouding in modern engine bays that finding a ground point is tough, so it is okay to hook to the battery post if you have to.

Comment: Only time will tell if Gorsuch is what he claims to be or not. For people who are whining about Merrick Garland, the simple fact is, Obama lack the popular mandate to appoint such a judge. By lacking the popular mandate, I am talking about Congressional control. The Constitution is very clear that the President can appoint someone to the Supreme Court but the Senate have the authority to "advice and consent" on that nomination. Ironically, the Constitution doesn't force the Senate to act on that nomination and if they choose NOT to "advice and consent", they can do that as they have done so in the past with Republican or Democratic nominees. In general theory, there is no reason to denied Gorsuch his appointment. Even the Democrats acknowledge that he is a superbly qualified but it matter of politics as it always been in the past. Its his stance on issues, not his qualifications that determined the votes. I am sure this will swing both ways, as it always done in the past.

Comment: This makes eminent sense. It also makes sense for courts, court facilities, judicial appointments and crown attorney budgets to follow the population curve. But there is a crucial variable, which is that trials simply take longer. Defences are more complicated, not merely because of the Charter of Rights and Freedoms but because the accepted definition of what constitutes an adequate defence has moved. And costs have moved with it -- lawyers' bills, attorney-generals' overheads, judges' salaries (granted, the least important factor). These things are seldom mentioned by solemn and finger-pointing editorials, which amount to simple-minded calls for  "More judges! More justice! " What they should be considering is "More time!" and what Time actually costs.

Comment: I am not one of the 1%'ers. However I have worked hard in life and earn a decent income. IMHO a tax rate of about 1/3 of income is about a reasonable tax rate, even for the "wealthy". But when overall tax rates on anybody exceed 50%, society is basically saying that they have more right to that person's money than they do, and I, for one, INTENSELY disagree with that. I started with nothing, no advantages over any other individual in this society. I put myself through university and worked my way up to where I am now. I pulled many a weekend and all-nighter to advance and still work hard to maintain my income. And yet many in our society feel that my hard earned cash is theirs to grab and squander. It's time the government worked on a basic, sound financial principle. Start with how much money you have and live within it. Enough already, no more taxes!

Comment: Bonds are useful as a thought exercise because bonds are usually issued for infrastructure projects which promise some future return on investment. The rail is an extremely costly infrastructure project which does not promise substantial benefit to the city in tax receipts or gains in productivity. That alone should raise the question of whether we should continue funding it.

The lack of clarity on expected costs is telling. Caldwell doesn't know how much the rail will cost, and you're correct that it's impossible to make a sound decision without that information. But the idea that the expected $5.2B in benefits has not changed is dubious. That calculation assumed timely completion of the full line. Neither of those conditions can be obtained at this point.

The bus is still useful to you because you have the potential to benefit. If your car breaks down, you could take the bus. This is not true of the rail. If you live in Kailua, you cannot take the rail for any usual purpose.

Comment: 'Clean audits, which have become the holy grail of good governance.' No, Helen, 'clean audit', which is often misunderstood by those in government, is ONE of the indicators of good governance. In 2015 http://www.politicsweb.co.za/news-and-analysis/clean-audits-and-their-unintended-consequences--he she previously used the phrase 'holy grail'. Then she called for a reevaluation of the time-tested auditing system because of HER misunderstanding of the purpose of auditing and an audit sampling anomaly of library books. 

A clean audit -unqualified audit opinion and compliance with legislation as it relates to the financial statements - indicates sound FINANCIAL administration, which is one part of overhaul good governance. Government officials, esp DA, are so fixated on clean audits that they, and non-accountants in general, misunderstand the purpose of annual audits, which is to ensure the financial statements are free of misstatement and fairly represent the position of the entity.

Comment: To me it seems obvious.

You are no longer allowed a misstep. You are no longer allowed to be tired, frustrated, distracted, new to a position, naïve, eager, or even, gasp, incorrect. You can't express an opinion and modify it or even retract it under later scrutiny, as you examine it further. You can't hold a public debate, and see opinion shift as the debate occurs between the participants. If you do any of those things, the only solution is to be fired or to be pressured into stepping down. There's no official discipline, no behind the doors discipline, no public retractions and then a period of silence to let things die down, just summary dismissal.

Comment: User fees in health care are necessary.  As a home owner, I hate to say this, but it is apparent that primary residences - should be - subject to capital gains - at the time - of sale.

The proceeds should NOT be general tax revenue, but go into the individual's special pension account. This should not be subject to any sort of "fairness" adjustment. All of the amount should be designated to the individual.

The pension account should boost the monthly payout to the individual with a part of the amount going into a special HSA (health savings account), which is restricted in payout. If there is a balance in this account, user fees can be designated by the individual resulting in expedited service - a second line for "user fee" payors.

This will relieve the pressure on the young people, workers, manufacturers, energy consumers, and the general economy, from rising health care costs, and also inject capital into the health system to increase service levels.

Comment: It's the fastest team sport there is, and it's played in an area much smaller than some houses. Plus the players carry sticks. Yes, there's going to be stick fouls.

The clear foul in this case was Ovechkin's high stick, which began the sequence of events. It was deserving of a major penalty if not a game misconduct. Niskanen's "cross-check to the face" that the author laments was nothing of the sort. An off-balance Crosby fell into Niskanen's stick held steady at waist height. Unfortunately, Niskanen and Crosby were on a collision course at high speed. The result of the entire sequence, which lasted about 1.5 seconds, is a concussion to Crosby.

It's a tough break for Crosby and the Pens. But in play-off hockey players will go all-out to score goals, and to prevent them. Even if it means an injury. Ovechkin's slash aside- which did not prevent a goal- it was play-off hockey at its best.

Comment: The Executive Order is available for review at: https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2017/03/06/executive-order-protecting-nation-foreign-terrorist-entry-united-states
Chin's intentions are good, but misguided. I think it will be more difficult to obtain a temporary restraining order this time.  The new EO provides details on how the countries were selected for added travel security measures during the Obama Administration. It includes reasoning given by an Obama Administration document for each individual country. The temporary restraining order was granted last time when both sides said they didn't have time to prepare detailed arguments. The new document provides for exceptions, for example, hardship to a foreign national  who wants to visit a close family member lawfully residing in the U.S.
The travel ban is for 90 days until the Visa program is updated for security. The EO provides the details. There may or may not be more opposition to the updated Visa program.

Comment: It is only messy because you’ve conflated two issues.

Jesus had no problem at all pointing out and condemning sin, and withholding forgiveness from the unrepentant. He was not Santa Claus.

From the Catholic perspective the primary human rights involve freedom from attack or persecution for orientation. From the Catholic perspective there is no right to same sex marriage or to compel others to violate their religious beliefs by participating in same sex marriages in any way.

From a civil law standpoint, the issue of rights and whether they are violated are a matter of the law, first the Constitution, then statutes.

So there are two discussions: what should a Catholic advocate for in the way of laws; what are the laws and what should they be?

The two may not be in synch.

Comment: Canadians mistakenly think their tax money goes to supporting 'Indians'. 
Indigenous peoples support Canada - not the other way around.  

The wealth of Canadians has, in large part, always been derived directly and indirectly from lands and resources that belong to Indigenous peoples, or were to be shared equally through treaties. Much of Canada is unceded Indigenous land - not crown land. 

The fact is that government uses the 'Indian Moneys Fund' - moneys generated by First Nations themselves, for transfers to Indigenous communities.

The fact is government spends far less on Indigenous people than on non-Indigenous Canadians - about 30% less. Healthcare? Education? Housing? Clean water infrastructure?

They are not 'special rights', they are treaty rights. Canada only exists as a result of treaties - treaties that Canada signed on to and now must fulfill.  

Indigenous people will "stop playing the victim" when governments and non-Indigenous Canadians stop victimizing 'Indians'.

Comment: I remember watching these military parades as a child. I was so excited and proud to see all the boots, guns, tanks, and missiles gleaming in the sun. One year I babbled on about how great the big parade was to my grandmother. She became very quiet. I asked her what was the matter. She looked sad and responded, "Those things kill grandmothers, and grandmothers' grandsons, too." Then she excused herself and went to her bedroom. It was a tiny apartment, so I could hear her crying. I was petrified, like any young adolescent boy would be. After a few minutes she came out, red eyed, and sat back down to finish the tea and strawberries. I felt terrible and started to cry. She gave me a hug, dried my eyes, and gave me more cake and strawberry preserve. I never went to another military parade again.

Comment: Rational is that a lower paid GP is a filter to ensure that patients do not needlessly tie up a higher paid specialist's time. But I bet our family GP still bills the system for that referral.

In metro Vancouver there is a shortage of GPs who will take on new patients, so the walk-in medical clinics are packed.  Often they reach their billable limit by the afternoon, so they cannot take any more patients for the day.So where do people end up?  Yeah, at the emergency ward.  

Richmond with it's high percentage of new immigrants, and those living here on 10 year visas, is a great user of clinics and the emergency ward.  One of the radio stations does an "average waitlist" announcement at regional hospitals.  RGH is usually longest. 

Inefficient yes

Comment: "Remember, [Hallowe'en] was the day where children would dress up as something they were not." Well not exactly, it's quite the reverse. Hallowe'en was the day when people would dress up as *the someone they most profoundly were, or yearned deep-down that they could bring into the light of day and make real* -- like the Lord of Misrule and Twelfth Night. On Hallowe'en and holidays like it, they were allowed to liberate their real selves from the bondage of their everyday roles and their orthodox politesse -- from their scripts in the theatre of propriety and ordinary life. However, our fastidious and hypersensitive age has lost touch with the rich, wise past and has turned things on their heads. It is now transforming one of our very few intervals of liberation into a day on which we must intensify the conventions and repressions that we act out during the rest of the year. Today's Hallowe'en is a masquerade all right -- it's a travesty of the "holidays" of yesteryear.

Comment: William,

Arguably, you are underestimating the effect that a legislated schedule of annual carbon tax rates increases (revenue neutral & progressive through rebates geared to low-income consumers).  These rates can start at modest levels & needn't increase dramatically each year because the fact that 

(a) the tax applies to every carbon emission related purchase, & 

(b) it is clear to all consumers, marketers & producers of carbon emission related products that over a few years the accumulated cost of these products will increase significantly unless emissions are reduced,

will be a constant incentive to purchase, market & produce improved products from a carbon emission standpoint.

There is no need to jump to a $200 per ton rate cold turkey & the goal is for the marketplace to induce us all to avoid the impact of the tax by changes over time in the products consumed, marketed and produced.

Comment: 'Critical insolation–CO2 relation for diagnosing past and future glacial inception' Nature (2016)

"Using an ensemble of simulations generated by an Earth system model of intermediate complexity constrained by palaeoclimatic data, we suggest that glacial inception was narrowly missed before the beginning of the Industrial Revolution. The missed inception can be accounted for by the combined effect of relatively high late-Holocene CO2 concentrations and the low orbital eccentricity of the Earth. Additionally, our analysis suggests that even in the absence of human perturbations no substantial build-up of ice sheets would occur within the next several thousand years and that the current interglacial would probably last for another 50,000 years. However, moderate anthropogenic cumulative CO2 emissions of 1,000 to 1,500 gigatonnes of carbon will postpone the next glacial inception by at least 100,000 years."

http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v529/n7585/full/nature16494.html

Comment: PS. I would not describe the restaurant royalty outfits as dividend growth stocks in that they do not have regular annual dividend increases. Comment: AST is a great organization, but they get taken advantage of in some areas. The APD-AST issue over Girdwood is an area of legitimate issues for both organizations, but areas like Mat-Su, Haines, etc, really need to step up and either form organized police forces, or expand them to take on the responsibilities of their area.

North Slope is the only borough police entity that covers multiple jurisdictions (several other city-boroughs have cops, but only cover their small area). Mat-Su is the 2nd most populated area of the state, surpassing Fairbanks, but relies almost exclusively on AST (WPD and PPD being municipal).

The Legislature needs to push down some stricter requirements for either state taxes to fund law enforcement, and/or stricter requirements for borough and local governments to take on providing some measure of law enforcement in their areas. Mat-Su has been slacking for a long time in emergency services as a whole, and it can't keep going in an urban center.

Comment: There, we are back to this thing called "same-sex marriage." The fact that one has to qualify it as "same-sex marriage," implicitly demonstrates the inherent difference between a same-sex union and marriage. And then, when people point this out, and object, that if they are different they cannot be the same, at the same time, these people are publicly shamed, harassed, called names and vilified (in the name of 'tolerance' and 'inclusion', of course).

We can sit around, hold hands sing kumbaya all day, and make firm solemn, sacred resolutions that '2+2 is 5', or that 'this circle is a square', that is not going to actually turn 2+2 into 5 and a circle into a square. Truth about reality is not a matter of majority decision. Luckily. We can create our personal lala land, but that will not coincide with reality.

In a similar way, if people decide, even by majority decision, that a same as a same-sex union is the same as marriage, that is not going to make it into a marriage.

Comment: It seems to me that the brokers, who have apparently been cut loose, were cheating the qualification process and should have been more severely dealt with.

If Home Capital disclosed that they had discovered and remedied the cheating, adding that their volumes may be affected in the short term, they would have done everything possible in being forthright.

I suspect that they were not trying to deceive investors but were just trying to sort out their internal policies for checks and balances on their producers.

Fraudulent practices in mortgage lending is the Achilles heel of this business. The 2007/08 meltdown in the US was precisely due to this issue and the lack of regulatory oversight that allowed it to go on unimpeded for far too long.

Some credit should be given to Home Capital for discovering the issue on their own.

Comment: The term 'double billing' refers to physicians who bill for services rendered under MSP and who bill for services rendered outside of that plan. If we are going to forbid such practice it would mean that no one working on contract to the federal government would be able to work for anyone else. The public does not own doctors or control what doctors do with the surplus hours they have after those consumed in our rationed system. The government does not have the funds to pay for all of the doctors' time so why should they be forbidden to sell it on a free market basis? It is not a matter of those who 'have money' getting better care - it is a matter of allowing people to purchase time and treatment that would otherwise go to waste. Double billing has no impact on the public system given that the services provided are surplus to what it can afford.

Comment: Mr Cestnick, you are the one being disingenuous, not Trudeau. This isn't about compensating risk-takers, as hard as you try to spin it as such. It's about removing increasingly used tax shelters that are exclusive to one group of "generally better off" class of individual and not others in lower income brackets.

Comment: All I have to say is that Gary Mason has no clue what he is talking about.  The vast majority of what he says is nothing more than unsupported speculation.  There is no data to support his hypothesis that speculation is driving up condominium prices.  Condominium prices have only  increased at half the rate of single family homes (based on MLS resale data).
The problem is a lack of supply of available land for the development of new housings.  There is lots of land designated for detached and semi-detach housing, but until all the services are in, the municipality has approved the development and, the big one actually issued building permits, that land is not available. 
BTW, there is absolutely nothing wrong with buying condominiums for rental purposes.  In fact, over the last 5 years about 60% of all condos have been purchased for rental purposes in the GTA (see CMHC data).  Without the condos there would be almost no new rental housing.  Thanks to rent controls, that will dry up to.

Comment: When I lived in Rome, I used to attend services at the Cistercian (Trappist) abbey of Tre Fontane. I've always been impressed by the Cistercian Reform of the Cluniac Liturgy, which consisted of stripping the Liturgy of all additions and celebrating it as it was meant to be celebrated, without accretions. The prayers are said with great respect, not intoned, and the parts meant to be chanted are chanted, not recited. Each gesture has a meaning, and no gestures are added. The result, in my opinion, is a Liturgy that speaks for itself: both simple and powerful, and one that doesn't require innovation. I think we've lost that in our parishes and we try to compensate by belting out the Lord's Prayer and holding hands.

Comment: Other problems in the article include equating stereotypes with myths when the former is actually an oversimplified image or idea of an issue.  Stereotype can also mean something conforming to a fixed or general pattern, which basically describes any analysis of data (in essence, the Commissioner is using a stereotype when she describes reasons why police forces have high unfounded rates).  The fact that she uses words like "Systemic discrimination in policing" is another example of a stereotype where the description fits perhaps "some" police forces but not many other.  
Her claim that the "end result is that some groups of people are overrepresented" in the criminal system glaringly overlooks the actions people in those groups may have taken to get into those situations (no, I'm not blaming the victim, just pointing out the nuisance of having standard laws in our society).  
Her suggestion on promoting underrepresented groups, while good, smacks of tribalism.

Comment: Sure, and Viagra can cause vision loss, chest pains, and rapid heartbeat. It rarely does so, but it's a possible side effect. And it's the possible side effects of cannabis you're naming. One of the most infuriating thing about any drug is that each of us has a unique biochemistry which reacts differently to the same substances. So while cannabis can adversely affect some people with panic and anxiety disorders, in most cases it helps alleviate anxiety. It certainly does in mine.

I have OCD, actual OCD which debilitates me if it's not controlled as opposed to the I've-got-to-have-things-just-so issue that most people think is OCD. It's an anxiety disorder. Cannabis helps my anxiety enormously, and it actually makes my prescribed medication more effective. I can survive without it, but it's much more challenging.

Comment: Briefly, this has more to do with the magma conduit to Pu'U "O" than to a magma chamber per se.  Right where this swarm occurred, the conduit from Kilauea to the East Rift Zone takes a sharp dogleg left at about Puhimau Crater.  Likely the conduit is quite fractured in this area, which along with the sharp bend presents an obstacle to the magma.  A large pulse of magma probably was released from the Kilauea magma chamber and when it hit this spot, backpressure developed and caused this swarm.  The relative inflation/deflation curves for Kilauea and Pu'u "O" support this (no sharp inflation at Pu'u "O" yet).  

Note that the magma conduit is relatively close to the surface in this area.  There's a 50-acre spot near Puhimau where the ground has heated enough to kill the 'ohia trees and most plants, with quite a bit of steaming in that area.  A very interesting spot.

This isn't the first swarm at that dogleg, but it's remarkable for the size of the quakes and tight clustering in time.

Comment: Not everyone needs home insurance. Not everyone needs renters insurance. Not everyone needs auto insurance. Not everyone needs liability insurance.

But everyone needs health insurance because everyone* will need to see the doctor someday (* perhaps there's the rare, one-in-a-billion case where a person never suffers any malady or gets into any kind of accident until the day they die). That's why it's different. That's why we should have basic coverage for all. Everyone pays in with their tax dollars, and everyone gets the benefit of basic coverage.

At that point, if you want more insurance? You're free to buy it.

You talk about freedom so much... what about the freedom to know that an accident or an unfortunate illness won't bankrupt you? That you can get the basic treatment and preventative services that every person needs? The kind of freedom that citizens of nearly every other country in the civilized world enjoys?

Comment: You might be interested to know that your physician does not operate under a fiduciary standard either. If a surgeon's business were run as Mr Hudson's the only way to be sure he does not profit by performing an unnecessary operation would be to pay him an annual fee whether he performs an operation or not. Unfortunately this creates a lack of incentive for the surgeon to perform any surgery as the pay is the same, and further creates a new incentive for the surgeon to spend more time looking for new patients that pay the annual fee. 
A professional by definition is required to put a client's interest before his or her own interest and there is no perfect incentive to assure you are getting anyone's best efforts.

Comment: Ljundgren writes that “[t]wo of the three measures of core inflation, which the Bank of Canada introduced last year, posted gains”, including CPI-common, which the BoC tended to push the hardest, which rose from 1.3% to 1.4%. However, surely this is hardly a strong point in favour of the BoC’s interest rate hike. In June 2015, the month before the BoC dropped the overnight rate interest rate from 0.75% to 0.5%, CPI-common was at 1.6%. The average of the three new measures was 1.5% in June 2015 as opposed to only 1.4% in June 2017. Journos like Lundgren seem to have completely forgotten the old CPIX measure of inflation since the 2016 renewal agreement plutoed it but it hasn’t gone away. In June 2015 it was sitting at 2.3%, above the target rate of inflation; in June 2017, it was at 0.9%, below the 1% lower bound. Poloz seems to have divorced his interest rate decisions almost completely from the inflation concerns that are supposed to dictate them.

Comment: It seems to me that "ghosting" is often connected to networks of people.   It's a form of bullying when that happens.  Isolation is recognized as a form of psychological abuse and ghosting by groups fits that.

There's a variant of ghosting called using the "lightswitch" technique.  The lightswitch is when someone completely controls the communication in a relationship by not responding for long periods of time to communications from someone else -- basically, they turn you "on" and "off".   "Temporary" can be years.   I used to fall prey to this a lot until I realized it often involved manipulation -- again, some form of network is often involved.   The lightswitch is tricky to distinguish from normal lapses that result because of distance and busy lives that both sides understand.  Judgment taking into account circumstances is key.

European families do not live and grow up in sandwich towers, tens of storeys in the sky: that lifestyle is for corporate offices and other commercial activities. Comment: While it's often more fun (and easier) to create a straw man than it is to actually address the issue at hand, no one is controlling anyone's opinion, nor should anyone want to (debate is what makes talking about the news interesting, after all!)

When sites turn off their comments section, they effectively silence everyone. But personal attacks, harassment, and abuse are such a huge problem in comments sections that many sites are turning comments off. The sites that *do* keep comments find they need to heavily police them through moderation.

If comments need to be moderated, it's more fair that the commenters themselves decide what is and isn’t acceptable behavior for their community, rather than putting that decision in the hands of one or two moderators. (And algorithms on the backend are, so far, doing a good job of preventing an echo chamber effect.)

Comment: Sometimes researchers ask about cannabis without asking about alcohol. Asking minors about their drug use helps us see trends, but it isn't very accurate. Answers depend in part on social attitudes. For example, Dutch teens are more candid about cannabis than Filipino teens, because Filipino teens face extrajudicial death squads. 

Where cannabis has been legalized and decriminalized, consumers are more honest about cannabis, which can give the false impression than usage rates are going up. Ditto ER "mentions" and poison control calls.

The most cited research on the perils of adolescent cannabis use is the Dunedin Multidisciplinary Health and Development Study. The study has found *correlations* between heavy, long-term cannabis use by minors and bad life outcomes. It has been criticized for failing to control for socioeconomic factors. Poor people also have bad life outcomes. Maybe childhood adversity leads to cannabis use and bad life outcomes.

Comment: Hexagonal close-packing is the optimal simple solution when the enclosing surface is large with respect to the size of the (uniform) circles, and leads to an asymptotic packing efficiency of (√3)/2.

But the problem is more interesting and complex when the enclosing polygon/rectangle/square is not much larger than the circles. For example,
https://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=pack+circles+of+radius+1+in+a+square+of+side+5 (experiment with variations on the side length of the square).

Not for the first time, a 'simple' problem in mathematics is actually deeper than it appears at first (or second) glance.

Comment: This is really a no-brainer. There is only one fighter on the market today that will be operationally relevant 20 years from now... That's the F-35. It's time to stop pretending that there actually is a real choice. Is it the perfect plane for Canada? Probably not. But if Canada is going to have a functional small airforce (capable of intercepting fighters and bombers) it needs to be stealthy with excellent sensors. China and Russia are developing their own stealth fighters which will be sold abroad reasonably soon. Frankly, once stealth is involved, you either have it or you don't.  Those that don't invariably lose unless you create artificial and unrealistic scenarios like putting a gen 4 plane right behind a gen 5 plane in visual range and yell go!

That being said, I think Canada is probably better off purchasing C rather A F-35's. Compatibility with existing tankers, extra range and the ability to land on shorter runways trumps the improved performance of the A.

So, when we had our own children, we didn't want them to struggle like we did and ended up getting everything they wanted, deserved or not. Every generation wants their children to have it easier, but a little hard work and respect for authority never hurt anyone.

Comment: IF your gay brother was dying of AIDS, would you deny him the resources to save his life? If your sister attempted suicide, would your prefer that the paramedics let her bleed out? And if your overweight father- bless his soul- had a stroke or cardiac arrest, is it better that society just let him pass... given that he didn't look after himself and all?

This crisis raises no unique issues as far as society is concerned. First we try our best to save anyone in a life-threatening situation. If the same kind of life-threatening situation continues, we develop a longer-range strategy. The greatest danger to us all comes from those who would, in a panic, unwisely call for Draconian measures that would damage everyone. 

As with health crises in the past, we will successfully deal with this one. In the meantime, please don't write off your brother, sister, father or anyone else who suffers from the human condition.

Comment: Wow DP. What a gross misrepresentation of the facts! There are so many errors and lies in this article. Let's cut to the chase here. Working for the State of Colorado is no panacea. I did a career with them. Most state employees make less than the private sector; I certainly did. Many people will not even consider working for the state on that basis alone. Then take into account some of the lousy tasks that must be accomplished by state employees. Prisons to road maintenance, you name it. Most not attractive or glamorous. Many jobs go undone because of inability to hire enough staff. Why do people take these jobs? One of the big reasons is the retirement package. Historically it has been looked at as deferred compensation. Why? In the case of licensed electricians, the pay scale is at least ten dollars per hour below scale. Kill the retirement carrot and Colorado is headed for big, big problems. Qualified applicants will simply not apply. Then what you gonna do? Call ghost busters?

Comment: Agreed, JohnK, this is a powerful column by Jason Lewis-Berry.  It's easy to forget that right at this moment  there are  still Americans in combat in Afghanistan, perhaps in a firefight, perhaps removing IEDs, in our longest most frustrating war ever.
My personal feeling is that because of 9-11 we needed to attack Afghanistan to deal with the Taliban extremists  who had attacked us.  For a while we had a popular war there and made military, social and political  progress, as L B noted.  
But then we took our eye off the ball when Bush et al  made perhaps the worst decision in American military  history, to attack Iraq; That caused us to shift resources and we lost momentum in Afghanistan and we're now in an endless mess in both countries.
And we're  employing  troops in Syria as well.
And the only thing I know for sure is that our combat Vets and their families deserve our profound respect and empathy regardless of the mistakes of our leaders..

Comment: I haven't listened to the HPR piece, so apologize if Sai is recommending clearing titles based on Kingdom law.  If he were, and HPR didn't report his conviction, then I agree the HPR reporter would have been negligent.

A distinction I'm hoping to make is that Sai's "theory" wasn't rejected in a court of law, it was the "application of the theory to land titles" that the court rejected.  I have no problem discussing other applications of his theory without rehashing or mentioning the Perfect Title story.  Sai paid his debt to society and has gone on to be a productive scholar.  I think his interpretations of Hawaiian history are interesting and useful and I applaud his attempts to engage a wider public via an HPR interview.  I also applaud HPR's interest in what island scholars are studying.

Two courtesy replies:  1) I'm no fan of Kellyanne Conway.  2) My archaeology reports are either published or public records--feel free to draw your own conclusions.

Comment: Media Bias Subtle, But Evident in PDN
Sorry to break up such an important discussion about the CRTC but I think it’s important to know how the PDN subtly reveals their bias.
The headline says, “McAleer appears to keep port seat…”. Use of the word “Appears” implies it isn’t certain the seat will be kept by McAleer. 
McAleer has 8,237 votes (64%) and Cobb has 4,721 votes (36%). That is a difference of 3,516 votes with 2,300 votes still to be counted. Even if all 2,300 outstanding votes are for Cobb, he’d still be over 1,200 votes short of a majority.
McAleer has won handily and the PDN should declare so, like they did in all the other articles where the winner has over 60% of the votes.
Congratulations Commissioner McAleer.

Comment: Damage, yes.  But a constitutional amendment to allow Trump to create an autocracy requires 2/3 majority support from both the House of Representatives and the Senate.  It then must be ratified by at least 38 of the 50 states.

Kendzior’s fears of an autocracy are unfounded – such an amendment would never pass.  No question that Trump is a bad president – but he’s not a dictator, and never will be.

What’s more, while the firing of Comey was extremely ill-advised and likely unethical, it was not illegal.  Trump was within his rights to do what he did.  So to call it autocracy or authoritarianism is inaccurate fearmongering.

Comment: John Kawamaoto, 

Thanks for the info on the Contingency Fund (CF).  You assert that 1) no corrective action was taken by management to control cost, and 2) it would be irresponsible to continue to fund rail.

1) HART construction contracts are fixed price contracts with fixed duration from the time notice to proceed is issued.  When a contract is signed, the cost is set.  The contract price is changed only when HART issues a change order (which is what a CF is for).  Unexpected events, e.g., a work stoppage beyond HART's control (from strikes, lawsuits and disasters, natural or otherwise) are not in the budget except as a CF item.

2) If funding for HART is cut off, It will mean $billions of Fed funds must be returned and $multi-Million to be spent to terminate existing contracts.  HART will receive no Fed funds after that.  Do you believe that's the better alternative?    

This will  be my last comment on this issue.  Sayonara.

FM

Comment: The market goes up and down. My wife and I found the bottom of the market in 1982 and 1990 were great times to buy. The only problem was that we didn't know whether to laugh or cry when Realtors waved pre-crash BC Assessment Authority Printouts trying to prove that homes should still go for top of the bubble prices. We did feel sorry for builders who had spent more on land and construction costs than they would get any time soon for the home they had just built.

When we bought our first home in 1982/March you only needed one hand to count the number of homes that were sold in all of Greater Victoria that month.

One problem that can show up when the bubble is about to burst is chains of "Subject To" sales. OK, I will buy your home at your inflated price, if I can sell my old house at a similarly inflated price. When the market stalls and homes stop selling the time limits expire and the entire chain falls apart.

Comment: Well, the historical picture is less clear, Gary.  There certainly is much evidence that women deacons existed in the early centuries of both the Eastern and Western Churches.  But there is considerable disagreement about if they were ordained or appointed, and if ordained, just what their functions as ministers were (as opposed to male deacons).  In the Western Church, Women deacons, too, preached the Gospel but only to other women, and went into places where men were not allowed.  The exact history of female deacons - particularly in Roman Catholicism - in muddied with twists and turns, regional and cultural differences, thus the varied interpretations.  By the twelfth century, women deacons disappeared in both Eastern and Western churches, it seems that menstruation was the reason for forbidding women being ordained to any clerical rank.  We need to see what the commission of the female diaconate comes up with and start a new conversation from there.

Comment: "Langley said she would request her transcripts as proof of enrollment at Cornell, but was told that a freeze had been placed on the documents because someone posing as her prospective employer was calling the university to obtain them."

 Cornell ONLY sends transcripts to the student whose name is on the transcript.  Anyone who has requested a transcript knows this.  The procedure for getting a transcript to an employer is to have the transcript mailed to yourself.  (I did this and my transcript arrived today in a sealed envelope.)  In order to give my transcript to a third party and have them know it is genuine, there is a clear notice on the envelope that says, 
         OFFICIAL TRANSCRIPT OF RECORD
                   CONFIDENTIAL
                  UNOFFICIAL IF SEAL IS BROKEN
Caltech (where I received my second degree has exactly the same procedure.

1. Canada's largest trading partner is thee U.S. - 80% of our exports - $348 billion out of $434 billion (CDN) - goes to the U.S.

Comment: JJ:  We have an economic system heavily dependent on the availability of a large pool of very cheap labor. We have created a need, let's make that a "requirement" that a significant portion of our neighbors live at the poverty level.  It's easy for some folks to blame the 1% and it's easy for others to blame those who are at that poverty level.  

However, such blaming doesn't change anything.  Frankly, at this stage of the economic "game", I'm not sure there is an answer.  If there is, we clearly haven't found it yet.  regards, Gary

Comment: Two notes: 1) Harry Neufeld is the former Chief Electoral Officer of BC; 2) the federal rules on third party advertising are reasonable and have been upheld by the Supreme Court.  In the new environment of fixed election dates, they may need some amendment to go beyond the formal election period (though that is open for debate) but they do provide a good model for provinces to follow.  Another area of concern in the federal rules is the appropriate upper limit on spending.  Some study is required to establish an appropriate limit in the Internet era (it might be higher or lower).  In general, however, the principle of transparency (i.e., the value of the registration requirement) is clear.  Social media posts demonstrate clearly the evil results of anonymity.

Comment: And, the Republicans are now using the same argument for why they won't repeal the ACA and replace it with something that works - "the Democrats are standing in the way." No, they aren't. The Democrats are currently a rump party that has very little power in Congress. There are Republicans who actually like the idea of the government taking over our medical care and leaving us with the non-care that the English receive (45% higher morality rate), and that is what is preventing an actual replacement of this bill.

I personally prefer eliminating all controls on medical care and medical insurance, but in the situation we have right now, opening insurance up across state lines and allowing people to pool into voluntary groups would allow all of us to get group rates like big employers do and that would drive down the high cost of premiums. The market is a much better arbiter of what medical insurance should cost than a government agency. ACA failure proved that.

Comment: No, Lee did not slaughter millions, and truth be told, there were aspects of his character that put most of us to shame.  Still, we have to see this through the eyes of black New Orleanians.  How would we feel if the chief warrior on the side of our ancestors' long oppression were presented like a diamond in a beautiful setting?  The statue of Lee, in itself a thing of beauty, becomes grotesque no less than a beautiful statue of a Hitler or Stalin.  The analogy of Lee to them is far from perfect, but close enough.   Physical beauty bends to the meaning of the thing.  Much as I will miss the statue --- I rarely thought of its meaning, but only of its physical beauty --- it was right to take it down.

Comment: That is not what the Surgeon General's report on suicide in the Canadian Force suggests. On the contrary, now that enough time has passed since the end of the mission for major mental health disorders to have by and large presented themselves, and and now that enough time has passed for decent longitudinal research to have been conducted, the data DOES exist to suggest there there is a statistically significantly higher risk of suicide among male army veterans of Afghanistan. Note also that this data is limited to those who are still serving in the military, who will tend to be the most functional on average. Veterans who have released from the military are NOT covered by the stats. The data does not yet exist for that; anecdotally it is appearing to many of us who pay attention that the suicide rate for released Afghanistan veterans is likely considerably higher. than it is for those still serving. VAC has pledged to have this data for December 2017.

Comment: I moved here a few years ago, I was homeless at the time. I lost my job, but was able to keep myself afloat for almost a year while unable to find work the entire time. At the beginning of April I had a 3 bed room home and all the furniture and household goods that go along with that, my two adult daughters living with me and a mother. By the end of May it was all gone, I lost the house so my children had to find somewhere to go and mother died. My sister offered to pay for our bus fare to move here, my husband is from Eugene. We are not drug addicts, we are not alcoholics, we are not mentally ill. If we had to stay at the shelter, I'm absolutely sure we would still be homeless today because there is NO help for people who are not addicts or mentally ill and have no dependent children. You try finding a job when you have no address, no phone, and a 6pm curfew. Opportunity Village is the only reason we were able to have the stability to do what we needed to do to get off the streets.

Comment: Exactly.  With all this 'false fact' fur flying about, I'm reminded that throughout my life, I've felt our mainstream media had a definite slant (generally left wing but not always), and that while media couldn't outright lie due to our copyright and libel laws, facts could be massaged to fit what someone wanted people to think about a topic.  One example is the endless streams of studies (some with as few as 20 in the sample group) used to illustrate an idea someone wants to sell, even though studies with tiny sample groups are almost meaningless.  

In some ways I find this subtle orientation of facts more disturbing than outright lies.  Outright lies are easily disproven (as we're seeing with Trump and his coterie).  Subtle misdirection can be harder to pin down.  My feeling is that others in the population have felt this vague unease for a long time as well,  without knowing quite what it was.  This may explain the gleeful finger pointing at media by them.

Comment: I'd be tempted to re-jig it all and instead of a list, say "wholism" is actually the philosophy that binds major Adventist beliefs. 

Wholism is the idea that Christianity was originally rooted in Hebrew culture, in contrast to later Gnostic-Greek ideas that would later distort the rest of Christianity. The Gnostics actually taught that the Hebrew God Yahweh was an evil lesser god, and the material created world evil or flawed. Gnostics were the "anti-Christs" Paul and John were talking about.

Adventism is the most anti-Gnostic denomination today. We affirm the Creator and His Creation as good (Sabbath as memorial), rest as good (through the Sabbath), the human body as a unity (not something for an immortal soul to escape), that human functions are good (hence our health message), and have hope in a physical resurrection and new earth. 

I think a more philosophical or meta-narrative approach would be better to a laundry list that is getting longer by the year.

Comment: I both drive and bike regularly in the area. I was pretty skeptical about the bike lane, but I figured it was worth it for pedestrians in the area. That buffer between the cars and pedestrians, especially when it's rainy, is a very good thing. I commute to work through that area, and I've started taking Willamette by bike. It was unexpectedly pleasant to be able to travel straight to my destination, without curving around the side streets toward amazon path, then back over again into downtown. I drive that stretch too, and so far the delays are really minor, like a few minutes. Take a breath, people.

Time will tell, but as more people begin to trust that Willamette is actually a decent bike route more people will use it. Comment: Are you serious?  If you do not know business that well, then you should really limit your comments.  Have you ever heard of the term "overhead"?   Not everyone that you employ counts directly towards profit, and even the employees that you have are contributing to profit in different ways.   There are metrics to determine how much on average each employee counts towards to revenues.  Some employees are contributing a lot, and others are there for support.  For example, the travel coordinator that used to book my flights did not count towards profit but was valuable to us, consultants.  However, every hour that I worked was billable and counted towards revenues/profit.

Comment: I've been flying WestJet, Air Canada and other defunct Canadian airlines  domestically for a long time. 15 years ago you could fly for $250 from Toronto to Western Canada (Calgary, Vancouver). Decent leg room, two check in pieces of luggage included, no seat fee. Travelers had small backpacks, purses, laptops as carry on. Very comfortable flight.
After killing the competition WJ and AC started to strip down service: one checkin piece of luggage, then no checkin luggage. While jacking up their prices. Travelers packing up everything but the kitchen sink in the carry on was the logical expectation. Then seat fees, crammed seats. And you are happy now if you can get a $600 ticket to Calgary (before the add-ons).

So we are complaining because the service level dropped considerably while the prices more than doubled.

Comment: I notice that Ibbitson refers to some Eastern European countries as "particularly xenophobic" in this article, presumably because some of the people and governments of these countries may not share his enthusiasm for high immigration levels. Secondly, labeling entire countries as xenophobic does not seem particularly enlightened. The columnist may consider that East European countries had to suffer through decades of life under harsh Communist dictatorships, among other things, which led to more poverty, in comparison to Western European countries, for example. Therefore, there are fewer resources to share with newcomers. Also, smaller countries, with small populations, can be more easily overwhelmed by massive and rapid immigration and may not have the infrastructure to accommodate such rapid change.

Comment: I'm seeing the same old arguments about global warming and climate change here, so here's my take, which seems to stand alone. The amount of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere has increased from 280 ppm to about 405 ppm since the early 19th century - measurable, proveably true. That's about the same amount found in the Pliocene Era, which still had fully functioning ecosystems, flora and fauna, so it's not the apocalypse. Should we continue? Probably not, but hydrocarbons as energy sources are remarkably good compared to other source of energy. Why not find a carbon neutral way to produce it without requiring fossil resources, perhaps from plants that recycle CO2? How about reducing energy use in our many devices? Why not different solutions for different places - diesel is a great way to heat homes here, solar is better for air conditioning in Tucson - and any solution that mires people in poverty by limiting energy resources for them is a nonstarter. IMHO

Comment: Our president is not elected by democracy. It's a represented republic. It was designed to prevent what happened to the Roman Empire. Where everyone moved to city centers so that they were represented. See if you lived in the city, you had lower taxes, while the burden was placed on rural areas. They started having food shortages, because people refused to be in the country because of the higher burden of tax. The cities where ultimately a service industry, they shifted to mostly import of goods. They collapsed. See our founding fathers, wanted equal representation to prevent collapse. To prevent a group of wolves from deciding everything for a few sheep, so to speak. 5 times in our history has the president won electoral college and lost the popular vote. Out of 200+ years, only 20 years has a president not won both and all 5 times it was a separation of less than .5% of the voter and less than .0025 % of the actual population. That's how close this separation is.

Comment: Simple fact, employee related expenses as well as the expense of automation that replaces many of those workers are tax deductible.  This means that 'tax cuts' will not change the companies decisions regarding their employees.  If an employee can 'add to the bottom line' the company will tend to hire that person.  Tax cuts will not change this.

When a company needs to spend money to buy things or hire people to make money, they only pay taxes on the profit made, and they get to deduct the cost of materials needed.

The only effect that tax cuts will have is on the amount of their profit they get to stick in the bank.  After all, if they reinvested that money, it would not be taxed.  This extra banked money does not go to the government, putting more financial pressure on the government.  Employees do  not benefit, only the top brass and the owners of the company profit from lower corporate taxes.

If you want to compete with China on the basis of wages, expect a MUCH lower standard OL

Comment: Well, all taxes "constrain the ability of small business owners to accumulate retained earnings".  The tax on interest earned is just another tax.  You're not prevented from accumulating retained earnings, but you'll have to pay the same tax as if you had invested that money outside the business.  You can also take the money out of the business and put it into an RRSP or TFSA subject to the same tax sheltering limits as non-business owners.   The one problem I do see, is that once placed in an RRSP it is difficult to invest that money back in to your own business.

Comment: The USA continues to classify marijuana as an illegal drug.  Because of the peculiar US federal system and SCOTUS decisions on treaty implementation, states can act unilaterally.  That does not apply in Canada as illegality of drugs is an exclusive matter for Parliament.

"While in 2013 (the year before cannabis legalization) 739 persons were indicted for drug-related crimes, in 2015 that number raised to 1233. Cannabis is still by far the most seized drug, with 2015 being the historical record."

And Canada is not Uruguay - we take treaties seriously.

Comment: I wish we could see more of this work--shots from the exhibit aren't available online either. I like the way Georges incorporates the traditions of icon painting into his work. The pose he has chosen for the mother of God is the "Theotokos of the sign," which dates back to the first century. Mary is depicted from the waist up with Christ in the centre of her upper body surrounded by a a bright light. He doesn't actually lean on her--it's more of a hovering. Traditional for the Christ child to be depicted with a scroll representing the new life, the new law . . . an interesting detail to be dropped, almost suggesting the hellishness just around the corner.

Comment: wrong again, governments do not measure their revenue and expenses and call any excess revenue profit.  most governments except for the federal government cannot have an operating budget spending more that they receive in revenues.  if an agency fails to spend all of its operating budget, generally the excess is forfeited and goes back to the general fund to be use for the subsequent year's budgets.  if an agency is granted a budget and there is a revenue shortfall, the agency or agencies will be required to cut their spending.  on the other hand after a budget, if revenues exceed the budget, the agencies are not given more money to spend, it is kept for the next year's budget.  hence, you cannot use the word profit to characterize government fiscal operations.  BP is correct, you have a lack of understanding of nonprofits and governments, they are not similar.

Comment: JIm B: No court of last resort has ever ruled that fluoridation is forced medication or a drug.  In 2011 Port Angeles, WA and Forks, WA were sued by the anti's.  Here was the final ruling.
Jefferson County Superior Court Judge Craddock Verser dismissed the case Friday on the grounds that fluoride cannot be considered a prescription drug when used in a public water supply. 
The two cities, in their motion to dismiss the case, said that designation does not apply to their use of fluoride because the FDA does not regulate public drinking water. 
He wrote that the plaintiffs would have to meet two criteria to prove their case: that fluoride is a prescription drug under federal law and that it is listed in the 2009 edition of the Drug Topics Red Book.
“Because the FDA does not regulate public drinking water or drinking water additives, it is impossible for plaintiffs to prove that the first requirement for being a [prescription drug] under Washington law is met,” he said.

Comment: The conditions faced by many aboriginal Canadians, and particularly those living on reserves, is unconscionable. But we've never been able to come up with a solution that doesn't involve massive spending increases and even then any assurance that money will actually fix the problems. Personally, I think the federal government doesn't adequately prioritize or target its spending and could address some of the problems faced by aboriginals were it to change course. But the economics of providing services to far-flung reserves are daunting and at some point taxpayers are likely to balk at the price of maintaining the system mainly for the sake of doing so. Ironically, the rationale for the flawed residential school system was integration, but that concept has been so discredited that no other response based on integration is even contemplated.
