Comment: All of the 270+ presidential electors in the Electoral College from the enacting states will be supporters of the presidential candidate receiving the most popular votes among all 50 states (and DC)—thereby guaranteeing that candidate with an Electoral College majority.

95% of the U.S. population in 1790 lived in places of less than 2,500 people, and only a few states let males, with substantial property, vote.  It is unlikely that the Founders were concerned about presidential candidates being elected only by voters in big cities. 

Now, voters in the biggest cities in the US are almost exactly balanced out by rural areas in terms of population and partisan composition.

16% of the U.S. pop lives outside the nation's MSAs.  Rural America has voted 60% Republican. 

16% lives in the top 100 cities. They voted 63% Democratic in 2004. 

The rest of the U.S., in suburbs, divide almost exactly equally between Republicans and Democrats.

Comment: Actually I have two objections to faith based charities - both of which you allude to above.
1 - Almost all faith based charities regard some form of evangelism (spreading the word etc...) to fall under "good works" and thus be a valid use of charity funds. I don't share this view.
2 - At least some faith based charities that I know of require the recipients to be involved in the religion in order to receive help (attending a church service for example). I think this is morally wrong, because it is no longer a free choice when you are holding something that the person needs.
Clearly there are many people not bothered by the above who want to support religious charities, and that is their choice, but I prefer to give to secular, humanist charities.
Also, many atheists do give to charity regularly, and I, at least, find it mildly annoying to have people constantly assuming that charity is always motivated by religion.

Comment: The best way to raise one's wage is to invest in oneself so as to be more valuable.  Self improvement is not easy nor cheap and may require deferment of pleasure.  Nevertheless, to get up above the bottom rung wherever that is pegged requires being worth more.  The current trend of simply bumping up the minimum wage is not based on increasing the quality or ability or training of the work force which might improve productivity and thus improve overall well being.  With no improvement in productivity, raising the minimum wage can only redistribute the wealth and the redistribution will mostly affect those who are just hanging in there.  Those who make 50% above minimum wage will become poorer since goods and services will increase in price to pay for the higher minimum.

But the staff should have known it as it is a basic rule regarding the removal of passengers from a flight.

Comment: When MPs make endorsements, one way or the other, for their Leader, they also choose their (nominal) boss. Who gets to choose their own boss? Damn, what a luxury. In Charlie's case, let us be frank, we are dealing with a guy who represents a riding the size of France and requires "fly-in" access to reach its environs. It isn't in the "media world". It isn't a fancy place. You just grind, grind, grind, and keep on going. You drive back and forth in hail, snow, gale-force winds, traffic jams, joined only by a play-list or audio books. You fuss about every child you meet, their parents, siblings. Schools. Who has a pension? Who goes to University? Let's not be romantic. Being a working MP from an often desperate and always disparate riding -- isn't an easy ride. Not Toronto or the 'burbs. Not Montreal or Vancouver. But Canada. Charlie "gets" Canada, in both official languages. And he doesn't want any of his colleagues or his staff to "mail it in", "call it in" or work less than he does.

Comment: Cat

Yes but debt is relative. 

If a company has an extremely low-risk business model that produces virtually guaranteed returns of say 13%, then they can go out and borrow money to fund their business at say 5% and lock those borrowing costs in at a fixed rate for say 25 years. A company like that can carry a lot of debt on their balance sheet and still be a low-risk investment. One needs to understand each company's business model, what they do, their contracts and how solid they are, the term of their loans, the risk of changes in interest rates to them, changes in goods' and services' pricing etc. and how all of these changes can affect each company. The level of risk is very different for a company that sells a commodity vs. one that provides, for example, electricity under a 25-year fixed-price, adjusted-for-infation contract. 

If you look at one number, the level of debt on a company's balance sheet, you have learned essentially nothing.  

I realize you disagree.

SFI

Comment: One of the most serious misconceptions in public affairs today is related to an erroneous understanding of government insurance. Once government gets involved in providing insurance for any economic purpose, it no longer qualifies as insurance.

Insurance is about measuring risk and finding market opportunities to reduce the consequences associated with inescapable risk that exists as part of our lives. The market provides insurance against untimely death, against automotive accidents, against fire in our homes, against burglary, and the like.

 The market does not provide insurance against risk that we create on our own. For example, you cannot buy insurance against losing the lottery, against business failure, against losing a sports match. This is because those are risks we create on our own. Market-based insurance is about cushioning the results of inadvertent events that negatively affect our lives.

Comment: There are two different issues here.  (1) Law: what private activity is regulated and what private activity is not regulated. (2) Law: the DOH failing its duty to regulate thereby violating rights of due process, equal protection, and/or privacy.   Furthermore, govt must ably and fairly, in fact, regulate or else violate constitutional protections due private activities.  So, before reaching your conclusions, be careful to not presume interpretations of legislated statutes and, too, an agency's consequential administrative regulations. Comment: Incorporated doctors working in a small hospital or community clinic can cost share. They pay their share of the cost to run the space. After seeing a patient, the province pays a doctor the fee, and after costs, the doctor can keep some profit in the corp. These doctors can still each claim the small business deduction.

Services are not paid based necessarily on the time it takes to perform the service. In a perfect world this would be the case, but fee structures aren't set up that way. Also, teaching and research generally do not pay as well as clinical care of patients.

Go to a big academic center and you have doctors who are specialized in the services that don't pay as well, including teaching and research. They are good at those things and that is what they do most of the time. To make it more equitable, the doctors who do the better-paying things will share their revenue through an umbrella corp. These doctors would have to share the deduction. Taxes on them can be up 11-17%.

Comment: I'm disappointed, I take the bus everyday from Fairview (next to the Senior Center) to the University, and my route has been axed. With the new system, it looks as though I would have to take 2, possibly 3, buses, plus additional walking time...in short, it will most likely be as quick or quicker to walk to school. I'm a bit surprised that there appears to be only one route going to the University now - if any young people were going to use the bus system, it would be students. I have never had an issue with the frequency of the buses - the 13 route is once an hour (I think an extra one comes around between 8 and 9am). I don't really see how this system is better if it potentially involves more walking, especially in a cold-climate city like Anchorage. I also just think that more walking would discourage people in general. Ideally, it would encourage people to get out and exercise, realistically, it will discourage people form taking the bus, possibly killing the system altogether.

Comment: All the minutes of the Monetary Policy Committee meeting for 14 June said about US inflation was: “Core PCE inflation had fallen for the second month in a row, to 1.5%, its lowest rate since December 2015, although some of this appeared to reflect idiosyncratic factors.” Somewhat odd, since the US Fed actually targets the PCEPI, not any core measure, and its inflation rate was a stronger 1.7%, down from 1.9% in March. You really get an appreciation of what completely different tracks Yellen’s Fed and Calamity Carney’s Fed are on, if you look, instead, at the US HICP for the total population, almost exactly comparable to the UK HICP. (The only important sense in which it is not comparable is that it has biennial basket updates, unlike the annual basket updates for the UK CPI, which is also the UK HICP. This should, if both the UK and the US had the same true inflation rate, make the US inflation rate appear slightly higher.)

Comment: If you offer something of value to the holder of a public office in direct exchange for their support on a particular issue, that's a bribe.  
Granted, it's pretty thin in real life.  You can say "I'm contributing $500 to your campaign" and that's a simple contribution.  
If you say, "I'm contributing $500 to your campaign and I expect you to vote yes on my issue, or I'm not giving it to you." that's an attempted bribe, and that is a crime, even if they don't follow through.

No, it's not.
In the "early days", milk would have come from local farms, processed in local dairies.
A much larger percentage of local produce, meat. etc. would have been available.
Nowadays all food is designed to be easily and efficiently shipped, flavor is a secondary concern.

I understand having neither the time nor disposition to shop, but don't give me this retro/nostalgia gloss to cover up the industrial nature of the business.
